PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The proposed Qinghai Delinha Concentrating Solar Thermal Plant Project which will 
develop 50 MW concentrating solar thermal power (CSP) plant in Qinghai province in PRC is 
included in the Country Operations Business Plan (COBP 2012–2014). Considering the inherent 
risk of the first-of-its-kind CSP project and the narrowed timeline of the project implementation 
schedule,15 early commencement of a project preparatory technical assistance (TA) is required 
to (i) conduct the due diligence on several aspects of the proposed project (para. 11, main text), 
(ii) technical guidance during design, construction, and operation stage of the proposed project, 
and (iii) familiarize executing and implementing agencies with ADB’s procurement procedure, 
disbursement procedure, and environment and social safeguards requirement.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
 
3.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000 equivalent which will be financed on a grant basis 
from ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TA special fund-other sources). The detailed 
cost estimate is in Table A5.2. The government was advised that approval of the TA does not 
commit ADB to financing any ensuing project.

procurement and construction works in July 2012 to ensure commercial operation in October 2014.

D.  Consulting Services 
 
4.  The proposed project entails innovative and first-of-its-kind solar energy technology. 
Being a new and emerging technology with limited expertise world over, CSP technology poses 
significant and unique challenges in approaching the firm-based consultant’s selection as TA 
7402-PRC: Concentrating Solar Thermal Power Development confronted.16 To avoid potential 
delay in consultant’s selection as found in TA 7402-PRC, the TA will take individual consultant 
selection method.   
                                                 
16 The Memo on TA 7402-PRC: Concentrating Solar Thermal Power Development-Change in Consultant’s Selection 
Method, dated on 6 April 2010.

16  Appendix 5 
 
5.      The TA will also take a unique approach (two stages of consulting services) to use 
efficiently  the  limited  loan  processing  time  and  to  effectively  guide  the  executing  and 
implementing  agency  since  the  initial  stage  of  project  preparation,  which  is  necessary  to 
improve technical and financial viability of the proposed project. Part 1 (preliminary design 
review and technical guidance, initial financial viability assessment, and advance procurement 
support) will require a total of 5 person-months of three individual international consultants and 
5 person-months of two individual national consultants while Part 2 (detailed due diligence, 
technical guidance, and capacity development) will require a total of 12 person-months of five 
international  and  15  person-months  of  four  national  consulting  services.  Part  1  will  be 
implemented while the selection of consulting services of Part 2 is underway. Early engagement 
of Part 1 consultant is essential to ensure quality of design, assess possible financial viability 
gap, and advance procurement support. The outputs delivered by the consultants of Part 1 will 
be carried over to the consultants of Part 2. The required positions and person-months are 
indicated in Table A5.3. All international and national consultants will be engaged by ADB in 
accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time).  The  procurement  of  equipment  by  consultants,  under  the  TA,  will  follow  ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). The proceeds of the TA will be 
disbursed in line with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended 
from time to time).

6.  The outline terms of references for the Part 1 of project preparatory technical assistance 
consultants are described in paras. 7 to 11. 
 
7.  CSP Engineer (1) (International, 2.0 person-months, intermittent). The expert should 
have post graduate degree in engineering or relevant field, and at least 10 years working 
experience  in  utility  scale  parabolic  trough  CSP  with  thermal  storage  design,  construction 
supervision, and operation and maintenance, with engineering experience on one or more 
commercial CSP plant preferably in operation. The expert will undertake the following activities:  
 
(i)  Review feasibility study report and other relevant documents to assess technical 
feasibility  taking  climate  and  geographical  conditions  of  the  project  site  into 
consideration, specifically on (a) solar field system design including loop design

Appendix 5  17 
 
and its configuration including solar field and plant layout and land development 
design, (b) heat transfer fluid (HTF) flow design, control and monitoring, freeze 
protection,  and  safety,  (c)  thermal  energy  storage  system  including  storage 
media, heat exchangers, storage tank design, freeze protection, and charge and 
discharge of  molten salt at initialization or emergent case; (d) power generation 
and grid connection including natural gas back-up system and air cooling system 
design; and (e) overall CSP system integration design.  
(ii)  Assess the project cost estimate including operation and maintenance cost, and 
implementation schedule. Identify technical risks and countermeasures.  
(iii)  Recommend  for  improvement  of  the  CSP  system  design,  cost  estimate, 
implementation schedule, and optimization of system configuration to ensure 
cost effectiveness in terms of leveraged cost of energy (LCOE).   
(iv)  Develop (a) initial technical due diligence report on preliminary design, and (b) 
brief technical guidance notes on detailed design for quality assurance of CSP 
system configuration and design.   
(v)  Visit  project  site  to  assess  the  status  of  preparation  and  readiness  for  the 
proposed subproject.   
(vi)  Coordinate  with,  and  consolidate  outputs  of  the  other  two  specialists  in  the 
preparation of an initial project assessment report comprised of initial technical 
due  diligence  report,  a  brief  technical  guidance  note,  and  initial  financial 
assessment report.  
 
8.  CSP  Engineer  (2)  (International, 1.0 person-month, intermittent). The expert should 
have post graduate degree in engineering or relevant field, and at least 10 years working 
experience in solar irradiation assessment and output yield projection for CSP power plant, with 
engineering experience on one or more commercial CSP plant preferably in operation.  The 
expert will undertake the following activities:  
  
(i)  Review  feasibility  study  report  and  other  relevant  documents  to  (a)  assess 
reliability of solar resource assessment data, (b) assess preliminary energy yield 
forecasting of the project, (c) conduct energy yield simulation, (d) recommend for 
improvement in solar resource assessment and energy yield forecasting.  
(ii)  Develop (a) initial technical due diligence report on solar resource assessment 
and energy yield forecasting, including energy yield re-forecasting, (b) a brief 
technical guidance notes for capacity improvement in solar resource assessment 
and output yield forecasting of the project.  
(iii)  In coordination with the CSP Engineer (1), prepare notes for solar resource 
assessment  and  energy  yield  forecasting,  which  is  a  part  of  technical  due 
diligence report:   
 
9.  Financial Specialist (International, 2.0 person-months, intermittent). The expert should 
have post graduate degree in finance or relevant field, and at least 5 years working experience. 
The expert will undertake the following activities: 
 
(i)  Assess  (a)  the  organizational  structure  including  ownership  structure  of  the 
executing and the implementing agency. Conduct initial financial management 
capacity and internal controls of the executing and the implementing agency. 
(ii)  Review the audited and unaudited financial statements of the executing and the 
implementing  agency  for  the  past  5  years  to  assess:  (a)  historical  financial 
performance, (b) heating tariffs, (c) capital structure, and (d) sufficient generation 
of internal funds to support sustainability of ongoing operations

13.   CSP  Engineer/Team  Leader  (international,  3.0  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
expert should have post graduate degree in engineering or relevant field, and at least 10 years 
working  experience  in  parabolic  trough  CSP  with  thermal  storage  design,  construction 
supervision, and operation and maintenance. The expert will undertake the following activities:  
 
(i)  Take the project team leadership and coordinate with all other experts on the 
assignment to ensure quality of work. 
(ii)  Responsible for the overall management of the project and liaise with ADB and 
the executing agency and the implementing agency during the implementation of 
the project preparatory TA. 
(iii)  Review initial technical due diligence report under part 1, feasibility study report, 
preliminary design, detailed design, technical parts of tender documents and the 
other relevant documents to conduct full scale technical due diligence taking 
climate  and  geographical  conditions  of  the  project  site  into  consideration, 
including (a) solar field system design including heat collector element (HCE), 
solar collector element (SCE), solar collector assembly (SCA), heat transfer fluid 
(HTF) system(HTF media, exchanger, oil pump and so on), and piping layout and 
its  auxiliary  components,  (b)  thermal  energy  storage  system  including  heat 
exchanger, molten salt, salt pump, and set-up molten salt media, (c) power 
generation and grid connection including cooling system design; and (d) overall 
CSP system integration design (e) technical specification of major equipment and 
material.

(vi)  Develop detailed technical due diligence report for CSP system design.

15.  Environment  Specialist  (international,  2.5  person-months,  intermittent).  The  expert 
should have post graduate degree in environment management or relevant field, and at least 10 
years working experience. The expert will undertake the following activities:  
 
(i)  Review domestic environmental impact assessment (EIA) reports, the feasibility 
study, and other relevant reports that were prepared by local institutes for the 
proposed project;  
(ii)  Review to ensure that all are relevant environmental laws, regulations in the PRC. 
If no sufficient regulatory frameworks existing in the PRC, propose and provide 
other regulatory examples that can ensure environmentally sound concentrating 
solar power generation with clear liability;

(iii)  With support from the executing and implementing agencies, prepare a project 
consolidated IEE report in English meeting ADB’s safeguard policy statement 
2009, specifically, Safeguard Requirements 1 (Appendix 1 of SPS); 
(iv)  Evaluate  environmental  impacts  identified  of  the  proposed  project,  and  the 
adequacy of environmentally friendly options, avoidance, minimization, mitigation 
and  compensatory  measures  (as  maybe  required)  to  address  the  adverse 
impacts associated with the location, design, construction and operation of the 
project, emphasizing those on (a) biodiversity conservation, (b) occupation of and 
community  health  and  safety,  (c)  physical  cultural  resources,  (d)  pollution 
prevention  and  abatement,  and  ensure  those  aspects  are  documented  and 
incorporated in the domestic reports;  
(v)  Assess and quantify environmental benefits of the proposed project in terms of 
GHG  emission  reduction,  and  other  associated  environmental  benefits  in 
consultation with Team Leader. This includes developing environmental baseline 
indicators;  
(vi)  Identify environmental risks and propose a set of mitigation measures;  
(vii)  Assist  the executing  agency  and the  EIA  institutes  to  prepare  a  sound  and 
comprehensive  environmental  management  plan  (EMP)  that  meets  the  ADB 
requirements. Ensure environmental baseline indictors and performance targets 
to be incorporated in the EMP; 
(viii)  Determine and specify monitoring requirements that meet the ADB requirements 
and prepare an environmental monitoring plan; 
(ix)  Assist  the  executing  agency  and  implementation  agency  to  disclose  the 
information to affected people and other key stakeholders, plan and organize a 
meaningful consultation process that meets the ADB requirements and record 
details of these activities and ensure that the views and concerns received are 
taken account of in developing the EMP. 
(x)  Plan, design and disseminate to the likely affected people a grievance redress 
mechanism (GRM) that meets the ADB requirements on GRM. Incorporate GRM 
in the IEE report;   
(xi)  Identify  and  collect  any  information  on  any  grievance  that  occurred  in  the 
proposed project area. If there is any record on complaints/incidents and how 
they  have  been  handled,  ensure  the  ADB  project  leader  and  safeguards

(xii)  Review  the  environmental  management  set  up  and  assess  its  adequacy  to

recommend institutional strengthening measures, if required along with a cost

(xiii)  Assess  the  capacity  of  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  on 
environmental  assessment,  management,  and  monitoring,  and  recommend 
necessary measures for capacity building; identify areas for improvement and 
training needs with respect to the environmental safeguard under the project. 
Based on this, prepare materials and conduct the training workshop to the staff of 
the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  and  other  stakeholders  on 
environmental management and safeguard;  
(xiv)  Review and revise the cost estimates of the proposed environmental mitigation 
measures and implementation of the EMP including capacity building training 
and environmental monitoring plan;  
(xv)  Prepare list of activities and budget requirements for independent environment 
monitoring and evaluation during project implementation;

16.  Social  Safeguards  and  Analysis  Specialist  (international,  2.0  person-months, 
intermittent). The expert should have post graduate degree in social science or relevant field, 
and at least 10 years working experience. The expert will undertake the following activities:  
 
(i)  Visit the proposed project site and assess the land acquisition and positive and 
negative  project  impacts  on  ethnic  minorities  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement 2009; 
(ii)  On land acquisition, (a) collect baseline information such as annual household 
income, size of land holding, source of income, education status of all affected 
households through questionnaire survey, (b) identify poverty households among 
affected villages through questionnaire survey and focused-group discussion, 
and identify type of livelihood supports which have been already extended or will 
be  extended  to  them  by  the  local  government,  (c)  assess  community 
development needs and opportunities through a series of group discussion and 
public consultation, (d) undertake meaningful consultation with villages to assess 
the level of their support to the project, compensation rate, and identify issues,  
(e) assess the  land acquisition process; 
(iii)  On ethnic minorities, (a) collect information through available documents and 
interviews on type of ethnic minorities residing in project area and population, 
and the socio-economic status and livelihood systems of ethnic minorities, (b) 
assess  positive and negative impacts of the project  on ethnic minorities in 
detail, (c) conduct consultation and prepare a participation plan, (d) develop a 
scheme  to  maximize  the  benefits  and  job  opportunities  to  the  local  people 
especially for the poor and women during the construction period, and (e) confirm 
the project does not restrict access to traditional areas (e.g. grassland) and/or 
affect their cultural ceremonial or spiritual use of land; 
(iv)  Prepare a combined land acquisition plan and ethnic minority development plan 
(LA&EMDP) in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statements; 
(v)  Poverty, gender and other social issues should be analyzed to consider design 
features that make the project more inclusive. Prepare a poverty and social 
analysis report that includes proposed measures that may be incorporated in the 
LA&EMDP.

21.  Economist  (national,  3  person-months,  intermittent).  The  expert  should  have  post

expert will undertake the following activities.  
 
(i)  Perform the economic analysis for the proposed project in coordination with the

(b) least-cost and equalizing discount rate analysis, (c) economic viability analysis,

E.  Reports 
 
22.  The  consultants  of  Part  1  will  submit  the  initial  project  assessment  report  upon 
completion of the assignment. The consultants of Part 2 will submit the following reports 
in English to ADB, and to the executing and implementing agency in Chinese: 
 
(i)  Inception report. It will be submitted within 2 weeks after the commencement of 
the services (3 copies in English to ADB and 3 copies in Chinese to the executing 
agency).  The  report  includes  a  detailed  work  program  plus  any  major 
inconsistencies in the terms of reference, staffing problems or deficiencies in the 
government’s assistance.  
(ii)  Interim report. It will be submitted within 12 weeks after the commencement of 
the services (3 copies in English to ADB and 3 copies in Chinese to the executing 
agency).  The  report  includes  a  preliminary  result  of  activities,  updated  work 
program, poverty and social analysis report, and any issues and concerns.  
(iii)  Draft final report. It will be submitted within 56 weeks after the commencement 
of the services (3 copies in English to ADB and 3 copies in Chinese to the 
executing agency). A workshop will be held, attended by relevant stakeholders, to 
get feedback on the report within 6 weeks after the submission of the draft final 
report including safeguard documents. 
(iv)  Final report. It will be submitted within 4 weeks after receipt of comments from 
ADB and the government on the draft final report (3 copies in English to ADB and 3 
copies  in  Chinese  to  the  executing  agency).  The  final  report  shall  take  into 
consideration the comments of ADB and the government. A maximum of 10 
pages summary report should be included in the final report.  
 
 F.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
23.  The executing agency will be CGNPC and implementing agency will be CGN-SEDC. 
The executing agency and the implementing agency will provide support to the consultants, 
including (i) arranging meetings with relevant government agencies and industries; (ii) providing 
access to all data which is permitted by the PRC law, including documents, reports, accounts, 
drawings  and  maps,  and  permission  to  enter  offices,  as  appropriate  and  necessary,  to 
undertake the work; and (iii) a suitably furnished office with utilities and telecommunication 
access.  The TA will be implemented over a 17-month period and is expected to start on 15 
June 2012 and be completed on 15 October 2013.
